I agree, good information. Pebble bed fuel at first glance appears to be a good solution, but when
looked at more closely it is terrible. The pebbles are very hard to make and IMPOSSIBLE to break down and recycle with current technology.
There are a number of fundamental problems of any solid fueled nuclear reactor. Nuclear fuel ALWAYS swells due to the intense radiation,
reaction byproducts quickly contaminate the reaction and cannot be remove from the solid fuel, unless the fuel is recycled. Also it only
allows utilization of a very small portion of the energy in the nuclear fuel (about 1-3%), requiring fuel bundle replacement in about 18 months.
When the core is decommissioned you still need to store the highly radioactive waste for thousands of years. Spent fuel MUST be
continuously covered in highly purified water for at least centuries to keep the fuel bundles below melting temperature. The continuous heat
from the fuel, evaporates the water quickly (hundreds of gallons in a short period of time) ALL spent fuel is currently stored in pools, on
site at the nuclear plant and there are no plans to recycle it as it is expensive and hard to do conventionally. Uranium is somewhat water
soluble (Thorium is not), so there is a groundwater contamination concern.

I used to oppose nuclear energy, mainly due to high pressure steam/hydrogen explosions (3 times so far) and long term
storage of highly radioactive fuel for 10k+ years. I have changed my mind, but only if we build Thorium liquid fueled, Molten Salt reactors (such as
LFTR) instead of the VERY expensive large, boiling water conventional reactors we have now. Currently Thorium is a waste product of a number
of mining operations, is orders of magnitude more plentiful than uranium and is basically as safe as dirt (it needs conversion inside the reactor to become useful
fuel, conversion takes 30 days and is free). Molten salt solves ALL of the fundamental problems of boiling water reactors, as part of their nature. They also cheaply and easily burn current stocks of used fuel rods leaving only a small residue that is safe in about 300 years. They effectively use about 95+% of the nuclear energy in the fuel. No
expensive explosion proof containment structure needed, as it cannot explode (it operates at ambient air pressure). They are walk away safe
(Oak Ridge Tennessee ran a molten salt reactor safely for 6,000 hours and performed walk away safe tests on it at full power in the 1960's).
In fact they shut it down every weekend because no one wanted to stay. They are well suited to the SMR form factor and easily allow continuous
removal of very valuable medical isotopes on an ongoing basis. These medical isotopes are impossible to remove from boiling water reactors.
They also provide high temperature waste heat that can be used in many high temperature processes now, such as steel, fertilizer or concrete
making, just to name a few. Desalinization of sea water on a huge scale is easy and cheap.

The only remaining hurdles are some slight metals compatibility proving needed. Chemical separation is a far
superior and cheaper process. The inventor of the nuclear tea kettle reactor (Alvin Weinberg) said it was fine for military use but was a
very poor choice for commercial reactors, as we have seen 3 times. For many years he strongly promoted the Thorium, liquid fueled reactor as a
far superior choice. Thorium is useless for making bombs which is one of the main reasons they used uranium instead back in the 1950’s. See
Thorium Alliance you tube videos for a good overview. An excellent boiling water reactor problems review is a 1hr You Tube video: Nuclear

Which nuclear? There are two nuclear fuel elements:
Uranium whose waste has components that will last 300,000 years.
Thorium whose waste is much less than uranium and has components that will last 300 years.
There are three nuclear fuel cycles:
Fissionable uranium-235 isotope representing 0.7% of all uranium.
Fertile uranium-238 isotope representing 99.3% of all uranium which when it absorbs a neutron will eventually breed into fissionable plutonium-239.
Fertile thorium-232 which when it absorbs a neutron will eventually breed into fissionable uranium-233.
There are two physical states to hold the nuclear fuel in: solid and liquid.
There are five forms that these three nuclear fuels can take: solid oxide, solid metal, aqueous, molten salt and molten metal.
There are three materials that a solid fuel can be immersed in: light water, heavy water and sodium.
There are two molten salts which are viable: liquid chloride and liquid fluoride.
There are six reactor technologies:
Pressurised light water reactors operating at 153 atmospheres (PWR).
Boiling light water reactors operating at 75 atmospheres (BWR).
Canada deuterium uranium pressurised light water reactors (CANDU).
Liquid metal fast breeder reactors (LMFBR).
Liquid fluoride thorium reactors (LFTR).
LFLEUR

I'm surprised that you mentioned nothing about small modular reactors. These are also designed in a way to passively Fail safe, and are considered so safe that the exclusion zone (Aria where no residential zones can occupy just in case) is only that of the reactor site, not 10KM like big nuclear plants.

They are also verry cheap as they can be built in factory's and take advantage of economies of scale. After the reactor building is built, Reactors can be installed one at a time allowing for more flexible budgeting, with power being generated while the rest are on order.

Maintenance is also cheaper and more cost effective. When a SMR site is at full capacity, reactors can be taken off line one by one for maintenance, allowing for no downtime. Unlike current reactors that have to be taken fully off line for 3 months while maintenance is done.

It can also be done on a JIT rotation, were the manufacture delivers a serviced reactor to the site, and then takes the one needing maintenance away. That will mean the downtime of that one reactor will just be a few hours during the swap.

Honestly i have to say, this video kind of felt a bit biased in my opinion.

First. I am not a Expert, nor do i claim to be. But as i am interested in all things technical and everything that has to do with disasters (sound wrong i know), i read a lot of books, watched lots of documentations and videos. visited an abandoned NPP in Austria (Zwentendorf), just to get to know this technology as far as someone that is not working in nuclear energy can. So some things are personal opinions and some things are what i found, when i read countless books about it.

I am not scared of nuclear energy, but i thing the problem is:

1. Many of the NPPs that are active today, are very old. And yes there is much upgrading going on, but its basically the same with an old car, you can modernize the headlights and the electronics, upgrade the brakes, put better tires on, but someday you are limited by something or it would be too expensive to do so.

Here in Germany all the NPPs we had are build in the in the early 60s to the late 70s. That is pretty old for something that basically can, in the event of a disaster, make huge parts of land uninhabitable for decades. Yes, you can say that the only really bad disaster that did that was Chernobyl. You can also say that that Chernobyl was operator error and that it also had to do with a mayor problem in the system (soviet union) itself, and that the chance of something like that happening to us in the "west" is pretty low or none existing. But the truth is, that something like that can happen. You just have to look to Fukushima for that.

In terms of Fukushima: Was it wise to build reactors so low to see level? No, not really. Was it wise to put Diesel generators and batteries under or almost under sea level? Not really. Was it as bad as Chernobyl? Probably not, because there was not a massive radioactive excursion like Chernobyl had (with much of the fuel "flying" to the outside), but non the less there are people that had to leave there homes and can probably not return for decades to come.

2. "not many people die, because of NPPs and nuclear energy!":

Well if you only look at the statistics that is true. Especially because, if someone gets cancer you can not link that to NPPs or nuclear energy directly. But you can also not say that it has nothing to do with NPPs. e.g. Here in germany near the NPP Kruemmel (AKW Krümmel) and the Geesthacht research reactors, there was a spike in leukemia since the 90s, when there were some "minor" or medium accidents in that NPP and the research reactor. As i sad you can not 100% link theses, but it can not be a total coincidence.

"many people die because of fossil fuels and its Power plants!"

Well yeah that can happen, if you live in densely packed environments, like very big cities. I dont think that many people living outside of big cities and small villages die because of pollution coursed by fossil fuels. Through that does not mean that its good to use them.

3. Then there is the issue with the NPPs fuel.

From what i found out. Most of the NPPs in service only use about about 5 - 10% of the total "energy" of a fuel road, before its removed from the reactor. I know that it has to do with balancing the fission and power output, through i am not claiming to be a expert. If someone can explain it, please do so.

Most of the countries that are using nuclear power have no way to recycle these used fuel road in e.g. in Sodium-cooled fast reactor or a molten salt Reactor (through those are coming with other problems as far as i know). Only thing that is being done more widespread is fuel reprocessing.


"But were do we put used fuel elements":

Well sadly the truth is, that at most placed it is just "parked" outside or in buildings near the NPP. Because most countries dont really have a solid way of storing these Fuel assemblies permanent. Only Country i know that has a solid plan for that is Sweden. (google SKB forsmark). In Germany we tried using an old salt mine for that, now they are trying to get all the waste out of there because of water getting into the mine.

So to come to an end. Is nuclear energy safe? Well in my opinion yes and no at the same time. On one point we didnt had that many accidents that made huge kilometers or miles of land uninhabitable. Only Chernobyl and Fukushima really managed to do so (well there was Kyshtym too). And yes not many people died because of the accidents itself. But at least for me, its not about what happend, but what could happen. Where ever humans are involved, there will be a chance for a mishap or a accident. That we can not change (because computers make errors too). And just because the number of direct dead that can be linked to Chernobyl or Fukushima is low, does not mean that the long term problem is gone. Because some of the people will maybe get leukemia or a form of cancer, or at least have higher chances to do so. Most of the radioactive materials that were set free by both accidents have half lifes of YEARS not days or month and that is only half of the time it takes to be "harmless". Do we need Nuclear at the moment? In my opinion, yes we do. Germany, the country i am from, decided to go without nuclear energy. Was is wrong. That depends on how much effort we are willing to make to get renewable were we need them.

The biggest thing limiting the construction of nuclear power, isn't the safety. A modern plant is going to be much safer, than the already reasonably safe plants of old. The real problem is, that solar panels and wind turbine costs have come down to a point, that Nuclear is among the most expensive sources of energy, surpassed only by off-shore wind. (according to the Energy Information Administration) While the cost of coal and natural gas continue to rise, the total levelized cost of Nuclear stays about the same, the cost of renewable energy continues to drop. The caveat, is that renewable energy is intermittent at best, requiring energy storage, to insure 24/7 power availability from the grid. Energy storage is expensive, putting Nuclear energy back on par with renewable+energy storage. With all the work being done on new types of energy storage, that too, is likely to come down on price as well, which will again, under-bid Nuclear energy. Just like in war, the "nuclear option" is an absolute last resort. Since nuclear is expensive, it can't be too great a percentage of total power production, or it will cause higher rates for the consumer.
Both sources need recycling programs, to economically re-use waste. Turbine blades, batteries, and solar panels are difficult at best, to recycle. Spent nuclear fuel and control rods have yet to be recycled.

Both, oftentimes, end up in traditionally underrepresented communities, most especially indigenous communities (particularly the Navajo), who usually have the strongest opposition to this technology for this very reason. They're afraid of the contamination from both of those things, and I have to say, I don't blame them.

With uranium mining, everywhere it's done, it does lead to an increase in lung cancer rates, even with the safest (and most often-used) method, in-situ leaching, it still has unresolved contamination problems. It's far better than the other methods (underground and open-pit), but it still has very real environmental problems.

For waste disposal, I think we need to do more research on where to store it, and not just dump it on communities that can't fight back. If we can get the storage truly air-tight (both in the literal and metaphorical sense that nothing can escape), and we can find places sufficiently far enough away from population centers (including small ones, like the indigenous ones mentioned), this can be overcome. Reprocessing could be an option too, but I'm not sure it makes much economic sense. The reprocessing costs alone make it hard to justify, but on top of that, the security around it would be high too since it can be turned into weapons grade materials, and in the end, it still ends up with some waste that is actually a lot more dangerous (although it does have much, much shorter half-lives), which, again, would need tight and expensive security since it could be used in weapons (i.e. dirty bombs).

First of all, I think your video is great at promoting nuclear energy. I'm an engineering physicist who graduated way back in 1991, so I have known for a long time that nuclear energy continues to be the safest and most energy-efficient approach on the planet today.

But I contest a single issue in the video. I find the "51 deaths" from Chernobyl to be extremely misleading. Certainly, the Soviet Union, with their lack of free speech would manipulate their numbers to their favor, so an official "51" number from their government shouldn't hold any weight in the history books.

The issue is with the radiation cloud that spread across Eastern Europe following the disaster. This link (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deaths_due_to_the_Chernobyl_disaster#:~:text=Of%20those%20in%20the%20exposed,7%25%20and%2050%25.)&text=Greenpeace%20have%20projected%20up%20to,deaths%20from%20the%20Chernobyl%20disaster) talks about the potential deaths related to an increase in cancer deaths that are likely connected to Chernobyl to as high as 60,000 deaths according to a UN consortium and as high as 1+ million according to Greenpeace. These numbers have been easily contested for the obvious reason that a direct link to Chernobyl can't be proven. For me, this is more personal because my uncle lived in eastern Slovakia at the time of the disaster (900km from Chernobyl). He was a hiker going on daily walks throughout the countryside as well as being a tour guide. He continued his work even while ignoring the warnings from officials of the nuclear radioactive cloud that engulfed much of eastern Europe (https://www.google.com/imgres?imgurl=http%3A%2F%2F1.bp.blogspot.com%2F-sj08HhAhCbI%2FU5fonU1VlFI%2FAAAAAAAAAus%2FsJwZBUr0nU8%2Fs1600%2FChernobyl%2BPlume.jpg&imgrefurl=http%3A%2F%2Fsowellslawblog.blogspot.com%2F2016%2F04%2Fchernobyl-nuclear-disaster-30-years.html&tbnid=KhEFBO6y0cARZM&vet=12ahUKEwjn8OquiOTvAhUapOAKHdTrD0YQMygFegUIARC-AQ..i&docid=X0XdecfjXWYZuM&w=1600&h=1038&q=nuclear%20radioactive%20cloud%20of%20chernobyl&ved=2ahUKEwjn8OquiOTvAhUapOAKHdTrD0YQMygFegUIARC-AQ)
Thirteen years after Chernobyl my uncle fell sick and was diagnosed with multiple cancers. Within three months he was dead. Certainly, his fate could be unrelated to the 1986 disaster, but with no history of cancer on his side of the family, we have always blamed his death on Chernobyl.

That said, I continue to be an advocate of nuclear energy and Bill Gates' work on nuclear energy is worth promoting. We as a society have not dealt with one very important part of nuclear energy: the long term storage of the waste. Most of the waste is currently sitting in pools at each nuclear power plant. There is no current plan for the long term storage. Deep borehole storage is not currently being used and would be a problem from an engineering perspective. Bottom line is that there are so many issues that need to be worked out and many of the issues are political. First we need to determine where it should be stored. Yucca Mountain is the best location based on many years of studying but the political will was not strong enough to overcome the local elected officials objections. Next we need to deal with the transportation issues involved with shipping high level nuclear waste to the final storage. Every community along the transportation routes will need to deal with issues associated with potential accidents. While the transportation casks have been tested, there is still the need to have the communities prepared for a failure of the safety measures.

Another issue that we must address is the need to modernize the plants to incorporate the latest technology and scientific knowledge. As we found with Fukushima, having a nuclear plant in a tsunami zone is not a good idea from many perspectives. The Diablo Canyon plant is being shut down due to its location being a dangerous place for a nuclear plant and it was not built with the potential disasters considered. New plants would be built with those necessary improvements. Closing old plants and building new ones will need to be done.

It will cost billions of dollars to deal with the waste and safety issues but we must do this. As is pointed out in the video, the issues with fossil fuel power sources are even greater and have not been properly dealt with. We need to overcome the political logjam that exists and start the process of moving high level nuclear waste to the final destinations.

Hanford (USDOE) Site
About the Hanford (USDOE) Site

The 586 square mile Hanford Site is home to one of the largest Superfund cleanups in the nation. Hanford is divided into four National Priorities List (NPL) sites. These areas are part of a U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) complex that includes buildings, disposal sites, the Hanford Reach National Monument, and vacant land. One of the NPL sites, the Hanford 1100 Area (190 square miles), has been deleted from the NPL. A partial deletion was completed for the Hanford 100 Area NPL, removing an additional 140 square miles.


Why this site is being featured
The Hanford Site is adjacent to the Columbia River which is the lifeblood of the Pacific Northwest. DOE’s annual cleanup budget of more than $2 billion a year drives much of the economy of the Tri-Cities area of Washington State. To date, 939 waste sites have been cleaned up, 428 facilities removed and over 17 million tons of waste removed. Over 12 billion gallons of groundwater have been treated removing over 157 tons of contamination.

The expected cost to finish cleaning up the Hanford nuclear reservation has tripled in three years, and that’s under the best case scenario, according to a Department of Energy report released Friday.



The report put remaining cleanup costs at $323.2 billion at best. At worst it could be $677 billion.



The cost estimates were included in the first Hanford Lifecycle Scope, Schedule and Cost Report to be released in three years. In the last report in 2016 the estimate was $107.7 billion.

“The findings of this report, and the developments on which it is based, show that a new approach is needed for the mission at Hanford,” DOE said in a statement.




“These increases have been years in the making and, while not unexpected, the implications are clear,” DOE said.

Estimates also have been extended on how long cleanup will need to continue at the 580-square-mile site in Eastern Washington state.


The assumptions included in the $323 billion estimate would require peak annual spending of nearly $9 billion a year, with cleanup continuing until 2079.




The high estimate would drag out cleanup to about 2102 and spending would peak at $16 billion a year. It includes a wide range of uncertainties associated with Hanford cleanup that could impact the cost and schedule.



Uncertainties include having to replace key facilities of the vitrification plant if treatment takes significantly longer than anticipated, that parts of the plant are not operating in the 2030s as required, that the aging 242-A Evaporator plant will have to be replaced, and that more double shell tanks relied on to store waste until it can be treated will fail.

The 2016 report estimated that cleanup would wrap up in 2066 and peak annual spending would be about $3.5 billion.




This year the nation is spending about $2.5 billion on managing and cleaning up the Hanford site.




It is massively contaminated with radioactive and hazardous chemical waste from the past production of plutonium for the nation’s nuclear weapons program. The raw material for these weapons were extracted from the spent fuels of the nuclear power plants at Hanford.



TANK WASTE DRIVES UP COST
Much of the increased cost in the latest lifecycle report is related to 56 million gallons of radioactive waste in underground tanks. The tanks must be emptied, the tanks closed in place or removed, and then the waste treated for permanent disposal.

A $17 billion vitrification plant is being built to treat the waste, but technical and other issues have made the project fall years behind schedule since construction began in 2002.



DOE’s faces revised deadlines set by the federal court in 2016 to have the plant treating low activity radioactive tank waste by 2023 and have the plant fully operating, including treating high level waste by 2036.

I've spent my working career in the nuclear industry, mainly in operations, but also in training, simulation, emergency preparedness and design. The most important aspect of TMI was probably the lack of any preparedness, and the poor training that the operators had received. The two major changes that came from this both significantly enhanced the emergency preparedness of sites and the local communities, as well as providing a standardised approach to training that was nationally monitored. INPO was set up in the USA and ensured a standard approach and regular assessments of training programmes. Following Chernobyl it became clear that what INPO was doing in the US needed to become worldwide, as any event had worldwide consequences. WANO was set up to mirror, across all nuclear sites, what INPO had originally started in the US. Every nuclear power station is now inspected every 5 years by an international team of experts, usually spending 3 weeks looking at a wide range of issues such as operations, maintenance, management oversight, health physics, training etc. A report is presented that covers all areas for improvement, and also any particular strengths, which are then shared with other sites to ensure they all match the best. Learning from others is a key factor in this process, driving out poor standards and ensuring high standards everywhere. I was fortunate to visit Chernobyl in 2006 on its 20th anniversary. I spent the day on site around the control room, turbine hall, external buildings, the old sarcophagus and several hours in Pripyat (the local town). My total radiation dose for the whole day was marginally less than what I got on the flight from London to Kiev. Yes radiation can be dangerous in large quantities, and its not easy to see - needing special instrumentation. But the industry understands it very well, and it is well managed. Radiation in the form of alpha particlaes and beta rays is very easily contained with very small amounts of shielding. Gamma rays may need thicker concrete of lead containers. People tend to forget that the ground from which uranium is dug is already radioactive. Yes, radioactive waste will generate radiation for many millions of years, but after about 100 years (I know its still a lot of years) it'll be back down to what it was when it was dug up. In the UK, our liquid discharge levels are such that we couldn't discharge mineral water as its too radioactive. The same applies to coffee grounds as they become low level radioactive waste. They're only managed on site as the canteen is outside the radiation controlled area. As another aside, Indian Point in New York wanted to build a coal fired station next to their two nuclear stations. They were stopped from doing so by the US nuclear regulator who stated that it wouldn't be allowed as the radation emitted from the coal fired power station chimneys would swamp the sensitive measuring equipment used to monitor the nuclear stations.

I would like to add to the points about low-level waste. In southern Ohio, the former site of the Fernald Feed Materials Production Site (a uranium processing plant) was converted into a massive nature reserve consisting of forests, wetlands, and prairies. The site was heavily contaminated (think 'polluting the water source and finding rotting barrels full of radioactive materials' levels of contamination), which ensued a massive cleanup effort. There are only two of the original buildings still standing, and there is a massive mound on the horizon. That mound actually contains 3 million cubic yards of low-level waste from the cleanup site - if you go into the visitor center, you'll see that, via a photo diagram of the mound's cross-section, most of the mound is highly engineered to contain and monitor potential leaks. None of the wildlife has been affected to my knowledge (there's even been sightings of difficult to find birds like the Northern Harrier and Rough-legged Hawk), and my family and I have had no ill effects from visiting the site, so I'd say as long as the materials are properly stored and monitored, they really pose no risk to anyone. That said, the past history of the site was quite dark/deadly and easy to forget when visiting.

Here's more info on Fernald if anyone is curious (this article also has a photo of the mound cross-section in the visitors center, but the whole article is quite fascinating): https://www.cincinnatimagazine.com/citywiseblog/what-lies-beneath-the-fernald-preserve/

You assert that long-lived nuclear waste is being stored in casks underground. The problem is that these wastes are more deadly than anything that exists in the world. If you stood next to "spent" nuclear fuel rods unshielded for even a few minutes dozens of years after it has been taken from the reactor core you would receive a lethal dose of radiation - that is why they have to be handled so carefully and stored away from people. "Recycling" the waste leaves reprocessing by-products that are both radioactive and chemically toxic. You can google the tank waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation to learn that taking the plutonium out of spent fuel and reusing it - in that case, for bombs - did not make the waste go away.

Regarding the theoretically safe and economic small modular reactors, understand that these are on the drawing boards and not built in real life. I suggest you google the father of nuclear power, Admiral Hyman Rickover's short paper, originally written in 1951 "paper reactors v. real reactors." You may also wish to read Dr. M.V. I'm a nuclear engineer that has worked at power plants for over eight years. I really appreciate the positive video on nuclear power, however I wanted to mention a couple of discrepancies in your video. The main one being about nuclear waste storage. The original plan in the 90's was to build Yucca Mountain in the middle of no where Nevada to store the US waste as you mentioned. However, due to politics the site was never commissioned (despite being pretty much built and ready to go). So instead, most power plants across the US use dry cask storage on site (above ground) or maintain the fuel in spent fuel pools in the plant. This storage has been proven to be safe and no major problems or issues have occurred, but this is far from ideal. Politics really get in the way of nuclear power innovation in the United States, as reflected by advancements in France.

Also, Chernobyl was a terrible disaster that literally can never occur in the United States due to how our plants are built and our government regulations, however this video really downplayed the disaster in a way that is disrespectful. The fallout affected many people across much of Europe. Yes, there are only 51 confirmed documented deaths, but that was in the 80's in Soviet Russia and there are complications to that number. For instance, we know Russia tried to hide a lot of information. Some estimates are in the thousands.

It is better to discuss the Three Mile Island accident, as it is more similar to what could happen in the US today. As you mentioned, there were no deaths or major injuries. This is because the design of the plant allowed the meltdown to be contained and much better reflects our capabilities today. This is what people should focus on.

Hello guys, as a French, I'm quite used to discussing people's misunderstanding and fear of nuclear energy since, as stated in the video, we get more than 70% of our electricity from nuclear power plants, and I'm very glad you guys tackled the challenge of explaining why our fear of it is so irrational.
First, Real Engineering's video on the cost of nuclear is pretty simplistic and full of wrong statements. There is a very good comment debunking most of it from one of my fellow Frenchman in the comment section that I encourage you to read if it interests you.

Now, on the health effects, I'd just add that the death toll you gave for the 3 main nuclear accidents, despite being right, can seem far from other estimates. So I'll explain why below in anticipation of comments addressing this. The main reason is that we have never been able to detect any statistical health effects for absorbed doses below 100 mSv. (That doesn't mean there isn't, that means its is so small we can't show it using epidemiological studies. Remember the first rule of epidemiology : if you can't tell an effect from statistical noise, the effect is at most very tiny and negligible). The correlation being linear over that threshold (+5% cancer incidence/100mSv), people often extend that correlation to doses below 100 mSv, without any scientific basis. It is widely accepted that those LNT (Linear No Threshold) models greatly overestimate the adverse effects of low radiation doses, especially when it comes to doses below 30 mSv (so almost everyone). We still use those models to set regulation standards for obvious reasons.
Using those on the 700 000 most exposed persons at Tchernobyl, we get 5000 deaths, and 9000 if we add everyone in the world for 75 years after the accident.
This figure might be bigger than the 51 whose death could be attributed for sure or with very high confidence to the accident, but 1st, the link between those death and the exposure is really far fetched and questioned by most scientists, 2nd no epidemiological study will ever be able to show that (it's way way way below statistical significance, I mean, 9000 deaths over the whole world and over 75 years ?!) and 3rd, it still is only 3 times the number of people who die in car crashes every year in France only. So basically nothing.
That being said, nuclear accidents' health consequences are more than just exposure to radiation, there are economic and social consequences such as people having to move out (200 000 people at Tchernobyl) that can lead to losing their jobs and income, depressions, segregation (people from contaminated area were feared by others and rejected), lower living standards, alcoholism... etc. But again, it also coincided with the collapse of the Soviet Union so it's hard to tell exactly what was Tchernobyl's impact. (Again, the rule is : if you can barely tell an effect from statistical noise, the effect is at most very tiny anyway).
In Fukushima, the official death toll due to radiation is 1, the scientific one is 0 (the state recognized the death of one worker as being due to radiations while it's hard to make the link, scientifically speaking), but the evacuation killed 2200 people (mostly old people that needed medical care that were not moved appropriately). People that wouldn't have been affected by the radiations anyway since cancers take time to develop.
So actually, the fear of nuclear energy leads to rash decisions which then leads to actual death. If fear kills more than the accident, I think there definitely is a problem.

Well, so, why is it a so widespread idea then ? Simple : nuclear is a fixed-costs system. As nuclear fuel is incredibly cheap, and yearly maintenance costs important (which you didn't talk about in your video but I will come back on it later), a nuclear reactor will cost you the same amount of money whether it produces at 25, 50 or 100% of maximum power. So a nuclear operator has all interest in keeping its plant at full capacity. And generally, that's what happens. In most parts of the world, including USA, nuclear is a small portion of electricity generation, so that consumption is always far higher than nuclear capacity, and so nuclear is running as baseload power. Whereas in France, because nuclear is a huge part of our electricity production, it is running in semi-baseload, which means it adapt itself to follow the average hourly consumption (decreasing power output at night and during week-ends and holidays).

Let me start by saying I am neither pro nuclear energy nor fossil fuel energy. I understand that there are pros and cons on both sides of the argument. I look at the energy production from the planet's point of view (as opposed to human perspective that usually is used in these types of discussions i.e. how environmental changes affect us as a species both on health perspective (i.e. cancer development for example) or mental perspective (i.e. we feel bad for extinction of other species due to our actions for example)).
I think that it is important to keep in mind that throughout Earth's lifetime over the past several million years (for which we have not been around by the way) there were literally thousands of species that evolved on this planet. They were born, they existed on the planet for a time and then they went extinct. It is a life cycle of a species (just as we have life cycle of individuals within a species being born, living and then dying so other generations can take their place). So let’s look at these two choices from Earth’s perspective. Fossil energy requires us to extract oil from the planet. That's like taking blood out of a body. I imagine that the planet needs that oil there for some reason (which we do not necessarily know right now) and us taking it out is just as bad as carelessly taking out someone’s blood. Eventually it'll show an effect on Earth’s health. Additionally, the by-product of using fossil fuels (as talked about constantly) is the carbon dioxide which is released into the atmosphere resulting in various consequences including warming of the planet etc. The much talked about carbon is something occurs naturally and can be found in and on the planet (admittedly not in the same quantity as what we produce however).
Now let's look at nuclear energy. It requires us using uranium (an element that occurs in very small amounts naturally in or on the planet). It also produces nuclear waste which does not occur in the natural way on or in the planet. Since we don’t know what else to do with it we bury that nuclear waste (no matter how carefully) into the planets core. I know the nuclear proponents talk about the measures of careful storage of that waste but let’s look at it not from human perspective (i.e. it won’t harm us) to the planet’s perspective. Imagine taking that nuclear waste, wrapping it in a “safe” package and implanting it into our own bodies. No matter how great the wrapping it is, eventually that wrapping will degrade (whether it is from the inside out (i.e. degradation occurs from the reaction with the nuclear waste) or from outside (the conditions from outside create for example a pressure that causes cracks in the wrapping). Eventually (admittedly this may take a few thousands of years but the point is that it will occur at some point) that nuclear waste will work its way into the body (or in the planet’s case, into the planet’s crust and maybe making its way into the planet’s core). Not good for Earth’s health. In fact, we have no idea what effect this would have on our planet’s core.
While the amount of carbon dioxide is alarming, baring that we stop producing it in such alarming quantities, over time (in thousands of years to come) Earth will be able to “digest” it (for example, store it in form of ice). However, since nuclear waste does not occur in nature, Earth will not know what to do with it or how to defend itself against it. While silicon carbide is strong in abrasion and compression applications, it does not have the same strength against expansion and shear forces. Some fission products such as xenon-133 have a limited absorbance in carbon, and some fuel kernels could accumulate enough gas to rupture the silicon carbide layer.[citation needed] Even a cracked pebble will not burn without oxygen, but the fuel pebble may not be rotated out and inspected for months, leaving a window of vulnerability."
